channel.title: The New Yorker — Reporting
channel.description: Latest reporting from The New Yorker

item.title: A Year of Convulsions in New York’s Prisons
item.description: How two murders and a strike exposed a system at its breaking point.

item.title: What Zohran Mamdani Knows About Power
item.description: The thirty-three-year-old socialist is rewriting the rules of New York politics. Can he transform the city as mayor?

item.title: A Tech Millionaire’s Costly Quest to Prove His Brother Was Murdered
item.description: Steve Johnson became convinced that his brother was the victim of an anti-gay hate crime. Decades later, a man was convicted for the killing. But did the police solve the case or perpetrate a miscarriage of justice?

item.title: A Forgotten Queen Bee of Modern Poetry
item.description: A débutante, a burlesque dancer, and a poet, the shape-shifting V. R. Lang—who died at thirty-two—wrote some of the most aching, entrancing lines of the twentieth century.

item.title: Inside the Trump Administration’s Assault on Higher Education
item.description: How conservatives learned to stop worrying and love federal power.

item.title: Donald Trump’s Deep-State Wrecking Ball
item.description: Russell Vought is using the White House budget office to lay waste to the federal bureaucracy—firing workers, decimating agencies, and testing the rule of law.

item.title: The Man Who Sells Unsellable New York Apartments
item.description: In the city’s turbulent market, Jason Saft doesn’t just beautify properties. He reveals the new life they could bring you.

item.title: The Cocaine Kingpin Living Large in Dubai
item.description: Daniel Kinahan, an Irish drug dealer, commands a billion-dollar empire from the U.A.E. Why isn’t he in prison?

item.title: Can the Golden Age of Costco Last?
item.description: With its standout deals and generous employment practices, the warehouse chain became a feel-good American institution. In a fraught time, it can be hard to remain beloved.

item.title: Gideon Lewis-Kraus on Rebecca West’s “The Crown Versus William Joyce”
item.description: The writer took on the trial of Lord Haw-Haw, a British Fascist who became a mouthpiece for the Nazis, and who prefigured the reactionary toadyism of our own era.
